extractedContent:
Application Number: 242832
Filename: SYRACUSE COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTER INC_Application-242832.pdf
Processed: 2026-01-23T09:08:03.101Z

compliantItems.element: Element b - Update of Needs Assessment
compliantItems.requirement: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.evidence: In the Project Narrative, under '5. Process for Assessing Needs, Updating Scope of Project, and Improving Service Delivery', the application states: 'SCH conducts an internal comprehensive community needs assessment every three years, including data related to demographics, social factors, barriers to care, and health disparities in the community. Many of the findings from our most recent needs assessment (completed in July 2024) are cited throughout the Need section above.' The narrative also describes use of the most recent UDS data (2024), county and state data, and references to external needs assessments (Onondaga County Community Needs Assessment and CHA), both conducted every three years. The application details how the needs assessment informs planning, service delivery, and strategic decisions, including recent expansions (e.g., portable clinic for homeless individuals, new residency program).
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear evidence that a comprehensive needs assessment was completed in July 2024, within the required three-year timeframe. The assessment uses the most recently available data for the service area and addresses demographics, social factors, health disparities, and barriers to care. The process is described as ongoing and integrated into strategic planning and service delivery improvements. The application also documents the use of internal and external data sources, annual reviews of UDS data, and Board involvement in reviewing needs and service area appropriateness. The needs assessment findings are referenced throughout the application and are used to guide programmatic changes, demonstrating that the process informs and improves health center services. Therefore, the application is COMPLIANT with Element b.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Sliding Fee Discount Program Policies
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance states: 'SCH offers two Sliding Fee Discount Schedules (SFDS), one for Medical/Routine Dental/Behavioral Health and one for Specialty Dental Services/Procedures/Prosthetics/Appliances. See Attachment 10 (specialty dental fees are in the far right column of the SFDS table). These schedules apply to all patients and families with annual incomes at or below 200% of the Federal Poverty Guidelines (FPG), including those who are uninsured, insured, and underinsured. The SFDS applies to all services included in SCH's scope of project.' The application narrative (Section 5: Sliding Fee Discount Program) describes annual board review and approval of the SFDS and related policies. The Bylaws (Attachment 2, Article III, A.1.ii) assign the Board responsibility for adopting policies on eligibility for services, including criteria for partial payment (sliding fee discount program). Form 1C confirms Sliding Fee Discount Program policies are on file.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear evidence that the sliding fee discount program policies are board-approved, apply uniformly to all patients, and are reviewed annually. The policies are referenced in both the project narrative and compliance attachments, and their board approval is documented in the Bylaws. The policies address eligibility, application, and uniform application to all patients, as required.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Sliding Fee for Column I Services
compliantItems.requirement: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 5A: Required Services Provided and Additional Services Provided show that all required and additional services (including medical, dental, behavioral health, optometry, nutrition, enabling/supportive services, and podiatry) are provided directly by SCH (Column I). Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedules presents the SFDS for all services except specialty dental and for specialty dental, with clear income brackets and corresponding discounts. The narrative (Section 5: Sliding Fee Discount Program and Attachment 13) describes how the SFDS is applied to all directly provided services, with specific nominal and discounted fees by income level. The SFDS is consistent with the policy described in the narrative and compliance attachments.
compliantItems.reasoning: The evidence shows that SCH applies its SFDS to all services provided directly (Column I), and the SFDS structure (nominal fee at or below 100% FPG, graduated discounts up to 200% FPG, and full charge above 200% FPG) is consistent with HRSA requirements. The application describes the process for determining eligibility and applying the SFDS, and the fee schedules are included as an attachment.

compliantItems.element: Element e - Incorporation of Current Federal Poverty Guidelines
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Schedules lists income thresholds for each household size that match the 2024 Federal Poverty Guidelines (e.g., for household size 1: $15,650 for 100% FPG, $21,910 for 140%, etc.). Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance states: 'SCH's SFDS is updated and Board-approved annually when the new FPG are released by the federal government.' The project narrative (Section 5: Sliding Fee Discount Program) also confirms use of the most recent FPG for eligibility determination.
compliantItems.reasoning: The SFDS tables in the application use the most recent FPG thresholds for 2024, and the narrative confirms annual updates and board approval upon release of new guidelines. This meets the requirement for incorporation of the current FPG.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Documentation of Key Management Staff Positions
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 4: Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff provides detailed descriptions for CEO, CMO, COO, and CFO, including duties/functions and required qualifications. Attachment 5: Biographical Sketches for Key Management Staff provides the training and experience for each key management staff member. The Project Narrative (Capacity section) references both attachments and summarizes qualifications and duties. Form 2: Staffing Profile lists these positions as direct hires.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides both position descriptions and biographical sketches for all key management staff, detailing required training, experience, and job functions. The documentation is explicit, current, and covers all required positions, demonstrating full compliance with the requirement.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: Form 2: Staffing Profile lists 1.0 FTE for Project Director/CEO as a direct hire. Attachment 3: Project Organizational Chart shows the CEO at the top, reporting to the Board of Directors, and overseeing the COO, CFO, and CMO. Attachment 4: Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff (CEO) states the CEO reports to the Board and is responsible for oversight of all programs and hiring/oversight of other management staff. The Bylaws (Attachment 2, Article V, Section 1.A and Article VI, Section 4) specify the Board's authority to select, evaluate, and dismiss the CEO, and that the CEO is responsible for day-to-day operations and staff oversight.
compliantItems.reasoning: The CEO is a direct employee of the health center, as shown in staffing and organizational documents. The reporting relationship to the Board and responsibility for day-to-day management and oversight of other key staff are clearly established in both the organizational chart, position descriptions, and bylaws. The evidence is clear, direct, and meets all aspects of the requirement.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements details all contracts and agreements, including their scope, how services are provided, timeframes, and processes for follow-up care. The Project Narrative (Response section) states: 'All our contracts and agreements are compliant with Health Center Program requirements.' Form 5A shows required services provided via formal written contracts/agreements. Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance states: 'All our contracts and agreements are compliant with Health Center Program requirements.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides a summary of all contracts and agreements, specifically referencing compliance with Health Center Program requirements. The contracts are described in sufficient detail to demonstrate that required provisions are included. There is no evidence of missing or non-compliant contracts, and the narrative affirms compliance.

notApplicableItems.element: Element e - HRSA Approval for Contracting Substantive Programmatic Work
notApplicableItems.requirement: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Part I, Question 2a: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: a) Contract(s) with another organization to perform substantive programmatic work within the proposed scope of project?' [X] No. Project Narrative (Capacity section): 'SCH does not contract for a majority of the required health services.' Attachment 13: 'SCH does not have any subrecipient arrangements ... SCH does not contract for a majority of the required health services.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: This requirement is not applicable because the health center does not contract for substantive programmatic work (i.e., does not contract with a single entity for the majority of health care providers). All required services are provided directly or through limited contracts for specific services, not for the majority of programmatic work.

notApplicableItems.element: Element g - HRSA Approval to Subaward (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Part I, Question 2b: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: b) Subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project?' [X] No. Project Narrative (Capacity section): 'SCH does not have any subrecipient arrangements.' Attachment 13: 'SCH does not have any subrecipient arrangements (Attachment 6: Co-Applicant Agreement is not applicable for our organization).' Form 6B: 'This form is not applicable to you.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: This requirement is not applicable because SCH has not made any subawards and does not utilize subrecipients. The application explicitly states there are no subrecipient arrangements.

notApplicableItems.element: Element h - Subaward Agreement (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Part I, Question 2b: [X] No subawards. Project Narrative (Capacity section): 'SCH does not have any subrecipient arrangements.' Attachment 13: 'SCH does not have any subrecipient arrangements (Attachment 6: Co-Applicant Agreement is not applicable for our organization).' Form 6B: 'This form is not applicable to you.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: This requirement is not applicable because SCH does not have any subawards or subrecipient arrangements. The application clearly documents this.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Coordination and Integration of Activities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.evidence: The application contains extensive documentation of collaboration with local hospitals (SUNY Upstate Medical University Hospital, Crouse Hospital, St. Joseph's Health Hospital), specialty providers (e.g., CNY Diagnostic Imaging Associates, SUNY Optometry Downstate), and social service organizations (e.g., Salvation Army, PEACE, Inc., Housing Visions, Blueprint 15, United Way, Brady Farm, Rescue Mission, Healthy Alliance Foundation). There are detailed descriptions of referral processes, formal agreements (Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements), and participation in community coalitions (e.g., Healthy Alliance Foundation, Housing and Homeless Coalition of Central New York, Maternal Mental Health Program Advisory Committee, I-81 Viaduct Project coalition). Letters of support from these organizations are included in Attachment 9: Collaboration Documentation.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear, specific, and robust evidence of active collaboration and integration with a wide range of providers and programs in the service area, including those serving special populations. These collaborations are documented through narrative descriptions, formal agreements, and letters of support. The health center also describes how these relationships are used to provide access to services not available directly through the health center (e.g., specialty care, hospital care, social services). This meets the requirement for coordination and integration of activities.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Collaboration with Other Primary Care Providers
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.evidence: The application states that there is one other HRSA-supported health center in the service area: Liberty Resources Integrated Health Care (an FQHC Look-Alike). The application documents efforts to collaborate with Liberty Resources, including participation in CHCANYS and regional IPAs (Upstate Community Health Collaborative IPA, FLIPA), and describes joint projects. The application also includes documentation of repeated efforts to obtain a letter of support from Liberty Resources (Attachment 9: Collaboration Documentation), with emails and phone call logs showing outreach. The application further documents collaboration with other FQHCs in the region through IPAs, and with state and local health services delivery projects (e.g., Community Health Connections Health Home, Onondaga County Health Department, New York State Department of Health, CHCANYS). Letters of support from CHCANYS and the NYS Department of Health are included.
compliantItems.reasoning: The health center has documented ongoing efforts to coordinate and integrate activities with other federally-funded, state, and local health services projects, including the only other health center in the service area. Although a letter of support from Liberty Resources was not obtained, the application provides evidence of repeated outreach and describes collaborative activities. The health center is also actively involved in statewide and regional collaborations with other FQHCs and health services projects. This satisfies the requirement for collaboration with other primary care providers.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Participation in Insurance Programs
compliantItems.requirement: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.evidence:
1. Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance states: 'As an established FQHC, we continue to maximize reimbursement for Medicaid/CHIP and Medicare visits through our FQHC enhanced reimbursement rate. We also accept most major private insurance plans. Claims are submitted electronically to all third-party payors (private insurance companies, Medicaid/CHIP and Medicare) by an external billing company.'
2. Form 3: Income Analysis shows projected income from Medicaid ($10,069,110.22), Medicare ($1,091,151.54), and Private ($800,080.73).
3. Project Narrative and multiple sections (e.g., Response, Patient Support Services) discuss eligibility assistance for Medicaid/CHIP and insurance enrollment.
4. Form 5A - Required Services Provided and Form 1A confirm the health center is a 330(e) CHC, which is required to participate in these programs.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear and direct evidence that Syracuse Community Health Center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and private insurance programs. The narrative, compliance attachments, and financial forms all confirm participation and billing activity for these programs. There is no evidence of exclusion or non-participation. Therefore, the requirement is fully met.

compliantItems.element: Element h - Policies or Procedures for Waiving or Reducing Fees
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.evidence:
1. Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance states: 'Per our Board-approved policy, patients or guarantors who are unable to pay are encouraged to create a payment plan (according to SCH policy and procedures). If a patient or guarantor is unable to meet the obligations of the payment plan, SCH staff revise the payment plan so that payments may be reduced to $5.00 per payment. If the patient or guarantor is unable to make the $5.00 payment, the President & CEO or CFO will review the patient's account and may waive all fees as allowable under statute. Only the President & CEO and CFO are authorized to approve such waivers and do so on a case-by-case basis.'
2. The same section also states: 'No patient is ever denied care due to inability to pay.'
3. Form 1C - Documents On File confirms the presence of 'Billing and Collections policies/procedures, including those regarding waivers or fee reductions and refusal to pay.'
4. The Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDS) is described in detail, including nominal fees and the process for presumptive eligibility and self-declaration for those without documentation.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides explicit evidence of board-approved policies and operating procedures for waiving or reducing fees, including the specific process and responsible parties (President & CEO or CFO) for authorizing such waivers. The policies are described as being board-approved, and the process is clearly outlined. The presence of these policies is further confirmed by Form 1C. Therefore, the requirement is fully met.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Budgeting for Scope of Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: The application includes a complete SF-424A Budget Information form, a detailed line-item budget and justification for Years 1-4, Form 3: Income Analysis, and narrative sections explicitly stating that the budget presentation is consistent with the Project Narrative and supports all sites and services in the approved scope of project. The budget narrative states: 'The attached budget presentation includes the SF-424A, a four-year line item budget/narrative, Form 2: Staffing Profile, and Form 3: Income Analysis. All budget-related forms and attachments are consistent. The budget presentation is also consistent with the Project Narrative; as detailed below, the budget reflects all sites and services detailed throughout the Project Narrative.' The budget aligns with the patient projections and service delivery plan, and includes all required cost categories (personnel, fringe, supplies, contractual, other, etc.).
compliantItems.reasoning: The health center submitted a comprehensive annual budget (total budget) to HRSA that includes all projected costs and revenues necessary to support the HRSA-approved scope of project. The budget is detailed, consistent across forms, and directly tied to the scope of project and patient projections, meeting the compliance requirement.

compliantItems.requirement: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: The SF-424A, line-item budget, and Form 3: Income Analysis all list multiple revenue sources beyond the Health Center Program award, including: Medicaid, Medicare, private insurance, self-pay, state government grants, private grants/contracts, 340b pharmacy revenue, MMCO quality incentive payments, contractual revenue from care management, rental income, investment income, and other revenue. The budget narrative and tables (see Table 13, Table 14, Table 15, etc.) break out these sources in detail. The total revenue is the sum of federal and non-federal sources, and the narrative explains increases/decreases and the rationale for each source.
compliantItems.reasoning: The budget clearly includes all projected revenue sources, not just the federal Health Center Program award. Each source is itemized and justified, demonstrating compliance with the requirement to include all other projected revenue sources supporting the project.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Maintenance of Board Authority Over Health Center Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: SCH Bylaws, Article V, Section 1.A: 'The governance and direction of the affairs of the Corporation shall be vested in a Board of Directors (hereinafter also referred to as the "Board"). The Board will be responsible for policy setting and planning, and for personnel matters relating to the Chief Executive Officer/President, including an annual performance review.' Article V, Section 1.C: 'No other individual, entity, or committee shall have approval authority or veto power over the Board of Directors with regard to the required authorities and functions set forth in these Bylaws... in no event shall such collaboration or agreements with other entities restrict or infringe upon the Board of Director's required authorities and functions.' Attachment 3: Project Organizational Chart shows Board at the top, CEO reporting to Board. Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance, Governance: Board Authority section, confirms Board is sole governing body and maintains full authority and oversight.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws and organizational chart explicitly vest all governing authority in the Board, with no other entity or individual having veto or approval power over Board actions. The application narrative and compliance attachments further confirm that the Board is the sole governing body with full oversight, and that no contracts, collaborations, or agreements restrict Board authority. This meets HRSA's requirement for maintenance of Board authority.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Required Authorities and Responsibilities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: SCH Bylaws, Article III, Section A, enumerates required authorities and responsibilities: (1) Establish general policies for operation, including financial management, scope of services, personnel policies, and quality-of-care audit procedures; (2) Approve the Health Center's annual budget, budget priorities, and grant applications; (3) Approve selection, hiring, annual evaluation, and, if necessary, dismissal of the CEO; (4) Measure and evaluate the Health Center's progress in meeting annual and long-term goals, strategic planning, review of mission and bylaws, evaluating patient satisfaction, and monitoring assets and performance; (5) Assure compliance with applicable Federal, State, and local laws. Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance, Governance: Board Authority section, cross-references these specific bylaws sections and confirms Board responsibilities for monthly meetings, CEO selection/dismissal, budget and grant application approval, services/sites/hours, evaluation of performance, policy adoption, and compliance. Form 6A: Current Board Member Characteristics and Form 8: Health Center Agreements confirm Board composition and lack of subrecipient or parent/affiliate arrangements.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws explicitly enumerate all required authorities and responsibilities for the Board as outlined in HRSA requirements, including financial, personnel, policy, strategic, and compliance oversight. The application narrative, compliance attachments, and forms confirm these authorities are current, active, and not restricted. Therefore, the requirement is fully met.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Board Member Selection and Removal Process
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: SCH Bylaws, Article V, Section 1.C.: 'No other individual, entity, or committee shall have approval authority or veto power over the Board of Directors with regard to the required authorities and functions set forth in these Bylaws.' Article V, Section 4: 'Directors shall be elected by the Board of Directors at its annual meeting and shall serve for a term of three (3) years or until his or her successor has been elected and takes office.' Section 10: 'Any Director may be removed for cause at any time by resolution of the Board of Directors.' Section 2: 'The Officers of the Board shall be a Chair of the Board and one or more Vice-Chairs... Officers shall be elected by the Board.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws clearly specify that only the Board has authority to select and remove board members and officers, including the Board Chair. There is no provision for any outside entity, committee, or individual to select the Board Chair or a majority of board members. The process for selection and removal is detailed and reserved to the Board, meeting HRSA requirements.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: SCH Bylaws, Article V, Section 3: 'A majority of the Board of Directors shall be user members who are or will be served by the Syracuse Community Health Center and who, as a group, represent the individuals being or to be served in terms of demographic factors such as race, ethnicity and gender.' 'The remaining Board members shall be representative of the community-at-large and shall be selected for their expertise in health care, community affairs, local government, finance and banking, legal affairs, social services, trade unions, and other commercial and industrial concerns, or social service agencies within the community; provided no more than one-half (1/2) of these members shall be individuals who earn more than ten (10%) percent of their annual income from the health care industry.' 'No member of the Board shall be an employee of the Syracuse Community Health Center or spouse, child, parent, brother, or sister by blood or marriage of such an employee.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws explicitly require a majority of user (patient) members, representation of the community, limits on health industry income, and prohibit employees and their immediate family members from serving. This meets all HRSA required board composition elements.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 6A - Current Board Member Characteristics: 17 board members listed, 9 of whom are health center patients (53%), and all members live or work in the service area. Board member expertise includes health administration, human services, business management, education, public policy, health care consumer, health care provider, human resources, finance, administration, legal, and advocacy. Only 2 non-patient members receive >10% of income from the health industry (well below the 50% limit). No board members are employees or immediate family of employees.
compliantItems.reasoning: The board meets all HRSA composition requirements: majority patients, representative of the community, appropriate expertise, income limits, and no employees/immediate family. The documentation is clear and complete.

notApplicableItems.requirement: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 6B - Request for Waiver of Board Member Requirements: 'This form is not applicable to you, since you are currently receiving or applying to receive Community Health Center (CHC) funding and/or you have selected 'Tribal' or 'Urban Indian' as the Business Entity in Form 1A.' Also, on the Summary Page and throughout the application, only 330(e) funding is requested; no 330(g), (h), or (i) funding or waiver is requested.
notApplicableItems.reasoning: SCH is a 330(e) (Community Health Center) grantee and is not requesting a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements. Therefore, this element is not applicable.
